bug.short_desc: Disconnect contextmenu should not be shown for "Local" systems

long_desc.thetext:
"Local" systems cannot be disconnected, therefore the "Disconnect" operation should not be shown for them.
This should be easy to accomplish by setting LocalFileSubSystemConfiguration.supportsSubSystemConnect() == false LocalShellSubSystemConfiguration.supportsSubSystemConnect() == false
Fixed. Took out the action for Local process subsystems as well.

When I select the Local System node, the "Disconnect" action is still there.
Looks like we'll need additional code that hides the "Connect" or "Disconnect" item from the System's menu, if there is NO subsystem that can connect or disconnect.
Overlooked the Connection actions. Fixed.

Closing old bugs.

bug.short_desc: [api] SystemBasePlugin.getIconPath() changed without notice

long_desc.thetext:
On April 27, 2006, the following change modified the documented API result of SystemBasePlugin.getIconPath():
SystemBasePlugin:1.5 ddykstal Changed the way images URLs are constructed. Used "/" as separator everywhere instead of File.separator. URLs must use "/". When packaging plugins as jars, the URL requirements appear to be much more strict.
Old clients who were used to do getIconPath() expected a result of "icons/" but now they get "icons"
I think the API should be reverted to its original state.
getIconPath was changed back to providing the trailing "/". All code using getIconPath (including samples and tutorials) was checked to ensure this was taken into account.

long_desc.thetext: Attached is the JAX-WS contribution. This is layer is the abstract support for tooling that needs JAX-WS support.
Created an attachment (id=46423) JAX WS Framework Contribution
Code has now been contributed to STP CVS repository.

bug.short_desc: CDT Indexer hangs on large initialised arrays.

long_desc.thetext: As part of our development environment we initialise large arrays of data that are used to program fpga's on power up. When the indexer hits these arrays (with up to 16K hex byte values) it hangs. We tried giving Eclipse 2Gb of VM but it still hangs. Simple sample project is available if someone wants to contact me.
Created an attachment (id=46424) Example of array indexer problem
Does it hang, or just take a real long time? I've seen the parser take a long time to chug through code like this.

We see it take a "real long time" (like 15 mins) on some cases. There's a cute little method
org.eclipse.cdt.core.parser.util.append()
That walks sequentially thru the array of elements looking for the first null. Get up to a few hundred thousand array elements and guess what?
Those utils seem to have some support for embedded nulls, but in the case of the parser that doesn't seem reasonable. Maybe we could add a fastAppend() that uses a binary chop for the parser? Or make the default fast (there are a lot of calls from the parser) and add a nullSafeAppend()
Created an attachment (id=53734) Patch to replace sequential search for first null element with a binary search

I would like to submit a patch for this bug. There is a method: static public Object [] append( Class c, Object[] array, Object obj ) in class: org.eclipse.cdt.core.parser.util.ArrayUtil This method loops sequentially through large arrays looking for the first null element. Replacing this loop with a binary search asssuming that the array will always be in a state such that all nulls occur after non-null elements. The patch replaces the sequential search in the loop with a call to a recursive binary search for the first null element in the array.
I have made changes to the Array

I have made changes to the ArrayUtil, see bug 162755. This problem seems to be fixed by this. I have added a testcase with an array of size 50K and it completes in about a second. I also tested 500K, which takes less than 5sec.

attachment.desc: Patch to replace sequential search for first null element with a binary search

bug.short_desc: [WorkbenchParts] New editor opened from existing one should be positioned at the same point

long_desc.thetext: New editor opened from existing one (RMB click on editor tab) should be positioned at the same point as the parent editor. Now it's necessary to remember the line being edited and first thing to do after opening new editor is Ctrl+L and jump to the same line.

Is this something that the text editor could check for when it gets the IDocument for an IEditorInput?
Is there some workbench support that is needed?
PW

>hm, IMO this makes sense for all kinds of editors, not just text Agree. The 'New Editor' action should decided whether to restore the selection and if so, do it for all editors not just text.
>I cannot find it, but wasn't there a discussion once about being able to open >an editor with an initial selection? The discussion was related to restoring the selection when restarting the workbench (see bug 124615 and its blocking bug).

Is this still a problem in 3.3?
PW
It is, at least in 3.3M2.

This was fixed as part of bug 124615
PW

bug.short_desc: [typing] When editing file in multiple editors each editor should have separate undo buffer

long_desc.thetext: When editing file in multiple editors each editor should have separate undo buffer. Right now they share undo buffer which makes editing file in multiple places (isn't it the point of multiple editors?) *very* painful.

Since multiple editors are editing one underlying resource (and model), and the changes in each editor shows up in the other editor, it makes sense to me that they have one undo buffer.
Moving to text for comment.
PW

Comment 1 sums it up - all editors operate on the same IDocument model and hence one undo history. Also, this would not work with the timestamp based undo model of the editor.
Susan, I believe you did most of the new editor undo support - Is the above correct, or would there be a way to have separate undo streams for each editor and only force a combined undo if the changes overlap?

In 3.1 and prior releases, the undo buffers were kept per editor rather than per document. We received strong complaints that we should be able to share the undo history per document, and this feature was implemented in 3.2 with a document-based undo manager. See bug #89599 (and its duplicates). There was discussion in this bug of exposing an option to control the behavior, but given the many requests for a shared model (and confusion caused by separate ones), we did not implement the option. It is still something that could be considered.

At work I'm working on files with 10000 or more lines (don't ask...). They have several functional parts. Now, if I have opened three editors, A, B and C, and I work with editor A on line 100, editor B on line 5000 and editor C on line 10000. Now I change code in editors: A, B, C, B, C, A, B, A, C, A. Now while working in editor A I discovered I made a mistake when working in editor C and I'd like to undo all changes in it. There are two serious problems with current behavior: 1. It's simply impossible without undoing changes in editors A and B 2. Cursor jumps around the file to places unrelated to the task I was working on. With complicated and huge files it's very easy to get confused what's going on and make stupid mistakes. With separate undo buffers I could treat editors A, B and C as completely separate editors, accidentally editing three parts of the same file and not three separate files.
I see your point but there are currently no plans to provide the option that Tom mentioned in comment 2.
Get rid of deprecated state.

bug.short_desc: RCP Tutorial is missing steps

long_desc.thetext:
I'm trying to run the small RCP tutorial that comes with Eclipse 3.2, I've followed all the steps, but when I click on "Launch the product" I get the following error:
java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter at java.net.URLClassLoader$1.run(Unknown Source) at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method) at java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(Unknown Source) at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(Unknown Source) at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:333) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:280) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:977) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:952)
I ran through the "creating a rich client application" provided in the SDK (linked from the intro page), and I could not get the error you mentionned. Is this what you used?

This is what I used, but now I think I know what went wrong.
In the step "Create the product configuration", if you don't select "Use a launch configuration" but leave the default choice instead ("Create a configuration file with basic settings") then the exception happens.
Since I selected the default choice, I think this exception should not happen.

I'm using Eclipse 3.2 as well.
I'm also getting the same exception, even if I choose a launch configuration.

The tutorial we're referring to is:
http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-RCP-1/tutorial1.html
Section "Making it a product"

I got the hint from the section "Troubleshooting" at the bottom of the tutorial. Not only was org.eclipse.osgi missing, but also org.eclipse.core.runtime, and the plugin project itself.
Solution:
1. Select "Configuration" tab. 2. Click on "Add" and choose "org.eclipse.ui.tutorial.rcp.part1" 3. Click on "Add Required Plug-ins" and Ctrl-S for save. 4. Click on "Overview" tab, "Synchronize" and "Launch the product".
Can the tutorial be updated with this information?

bug.short_desc: [api] SystemRegistry.postEvent() fails from Worker thread

long_desc.thetext:
When SystemRegistry.postEvent() is called from a Worker thread, an SWTException:invalid thread access happens. To reproduce the problem, uncomment corresponding code in DaytimeSubSytem.initializeSubSystem().
SystemRegistry.postEvent() should work from any thread, API doc should document this.
I think the bug is either in SystemView.getShell() where the underlying SWT tree is asked for the shell, or in SystemPostableEventNotifier.SystemPostableEventNotifier() where the Display is obtained from the Listener, instead of just taking Display.getDefault().
I've changed this to use Display.getDefault();

Created an attachment (id=46427) remove ResetAllAction
Fix for this weeks integration build: Remove the action.

Problem is that org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.wizards.buildpaths.BuildPathsBlock.doUpdateUI() calles init on the NewSourceContainerWorkbookPage with a potentialy (doUpdateUI is an async exec!) not yet created IJavaProject as parameter.
Solution: Need a protocol for BuildPathsBlock: 1. new BuildPathsBlock() 2. createControl() 3. init(IJavaProject project) or 1. new BuildPathsBlock() 2. init(IJavaProject project) 3. createControl()
with init requires: project != null && project.exists()

Second problem is, that the Action is initialized on finishing the first wizard page: The action shouldn't even exist. Third problem is, that ResetAllAction should use some sort of history. The history should be initialized, instead of the action itself.

Can't specify such a protocol, since it would lead to breaking API changes in org.eclipse.jdt.ui.wizards.JavaCapabilityConfigurationPage. Best fix I can think of is to register an IElementChangeListener if the project does not exist and wait until it does. (And of course don't init the BuildPathBasePages in a async ui thread)
Created an attachment (id=46630) fix

For second problem see Bug 151400
Third problem is an enhancement and minor, for later.

bug.short_desc: NPE in Remote Monitor when connection is disconnected while polling

long_desc.thetext:
Reproducable with Daytime, or Dstore-Linux-Processes: * Connect to remote dstore-linux connection * Expand "My Processes" * Rightclick > Monitor * Enable polling, wait time = 5 seconds * Wait for 1 poll to occur * In the Systems view, disconnect the Processes Subsystem
--> RSE brings up "An internal error occurred during..."

Created an attachment (id=46428) Patch for fixing NPE in Monitor
Attached patch fixes the problem for the Daytime subsystem.
With Dstore-processes, however, the actions from the bug description lead to a different, second exception and log message ("failed to connect %1"), an NPE in the dstore server, and a "Query Processes" job that doesnt stop. The Processes system remains shown "connected" and the whole RSE state seems to be broken.
Applied the patch - please review
I've added a check to make sure we're connected before attempting a poll query.
verified that it is fixed in 1.0RC3. No longer getting error message during disconnect.
Verified by Yu-Fen

attachment.desc: Patch for fixing NPE in Monitor

bug.short_desc: [filters] Restore Default Filters Button

long_desc.thetext:
Add a "Restore Default" button to the Package Explorer -> Filters... dialog box.
Use case: In the package explorer I select "Filters..." and select/deselect some of the elements I want to exclude from the view. Later I want to work with the "standard" selection Eclipse came "out of the box" but I can only click on "Select All" or "Deselect All". A "Restore Default" would seem helpful to me.
Good idea.

bug.short_desc: [filters] Reset Last Recently Used Filters

long_desc.thetext:
I may only reset the "last recently used filters" in the package explorer by editing the file ".metadata/.../workbench.xml".
I would like to "purge" the history manually or maybe define a history size to keep the menu from growing too large or give a time to live like the history in my web browser (e.g. Thunderbird)

bug.short_desc: "Do not echo input" - missing

long_desc.thetext:
Hi,
i use eclipse 3.2 with birt 2.1 and report engine 2.1.
When i design a report with the birt-eclipse-designer, i can create a TextBox with "Do not echo input" (e.g. for password input). This works fine in birt-preview. But how can i get the "Do not echo input" flag from report engine? The 2 relevant classes are "IGetParameterDefinitionTask" (e.g. getting default value there) and "IScalarParameterDefn". But there are no methods to get the "Do not echo input" flag.
Is there a magic trick to get these flag in the report engine? Is these flag missing?
Best regrads
-- orkus
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 150917 ***

bug.short_desc: [api] Creation of new subsystems should be simplified

long_desc.thetext:
It should be easier for clients to create a new subsystem:
Currently, each new subsystem needs to define its own ConnectorService, and ConnectorServiceManager. But the ConnectorServiceManager is just copied-and-pasted code in most cases.
A default implementation of ConnectorService / ConnectorServiceManager should exist, that can be re-used by subsystem implementers, allowing them to create fewer classes for their implementation.

bug.short_desc: [api] connect fails if SubSystemConfiguration.supportsUserId() returns false

long_desc.thetext:
When a subsystem is configured with SubSystemConfiguration.supportsUserId() == false
the connect sequence is broken, it is no more possible to connect. Can be reproduced with Daytime example and "Developer" (Tutorial) example.

Created an attachment (id=46429) Patch to handle SubSystemConfiguration.supportsUserId() properly
Attached patch fixes the problem.
Applied the patch. Please Review.
Looks good.

bug.short_desc: [api] Need to clarify if IPropertySet.getDescription() can return null

long_desc.thetext:
IPropertySet is lacking documentation.
IPropertySet.getDescription() should be defined whether it is allowed to return null or not. Same for public abstract class ServiceElement.
Currently, it is very easily possible to create a PropertySet that returns null for its description, and as a consequence ConnectorServicesForm.getCurrentVerbage() ServicesForm.getCurrentVerbage() may run into NullPointerExceptions.
I'd suggest that we explicitly allow the description to return null, and fix the NPE in the forms by doing a fallback to "".

Created an attachment (id=46430) Patch for avoiding NPE in ServiceViewer
Attached patch fixes the NPE in the ServiceViewer.
API documentation still needs to be written.
Documentation is a high priority for 1.0.1 I strongly recommend fixing this for 1.0.1
Documentation has been provided and the patch applied.
Documentation states now that IPropertySet.getDescription() returns null if not set, and code prevents NPE.
closing previously verified bug reports

attachment.desc: Patch for avoiding NPE in ServiceViewer

bug.short_desc: [api] IPropertySet should have setDescription() method

long_desc.thetext:
For sake of completeness, IPropertySet should have a setDescription() method.
The getDescription() method is used by ServicesForm and ConnectorServicesForm. For users who want to set a particular description, it is unclear how they can do so if they only know the API. It is an implementation detail, that they can set a property "description".
[api] Added setDescription() method

bug.short_desc: JNLP generation should only contains plugins for the config being built

long_desc.thetext: i create a build automation for my RCP JavaWebStart application. the generated *.jnlp-file for the org.eclipse.rcp feature contains all avaliable platform-references but only the win32 & linux reference jars are bundeled!
Do you mean that in the output, only the files for the linux and win32 fragments are available? How are you producing this build?

i producing this build with pde build automation . my problem is the following section in the org.eclipse.rcp feature jnlp:
<resources os="Windows" arch="x86"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Linux" arch="x86"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Solaris" arch="sparc"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.solaris.sparc_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Solaris" arch="x86"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.solaris.x86_3.2.0.HEAD.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Linux" arch="ppc"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.ppc_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Linux" arch="x86_64"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86_64_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Mac"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.carbon.macosx_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="AIX" arch="ppc"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.motif.aix.ppc_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="HP-UX" arch="PA_RISC"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.motif.hpux.PA_RISC_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Linux" arch="x86"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.motif.linux.x86_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Linux" arch="ia64"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.ia64_3.2.0.HEAD.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="Solaris" arch="sparc"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.motif.solaris.sparc_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="qnx" arch="x86"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.photon.qnx.x86_3.2.0.v3232m.jar"/> </resources> <resources os="HP-UX" arch="ia64_32"> <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.swt.motif.hpux.ia64_32_3.2.0.HEAD.jar"/> </resources>
every platform is linked in the jnlp but i only choose windows and linux!!!
Michael, would you like to take a stab at this one?
yes i can. but the next few weeks till midd of october, i'm very busy and do not have the time. is it to late to implement this on end of october?

pascal, sorry for the late replay but there was no time looking at this before.
after looking into the source code I'm not sure if this is really a bug. I will try to explain it to you:
every os-specific resources section for the jnlp is made cause the rcp feature.xml has a <plugin>-reference to a plugin for this os. the references in the feature.xml of the rcp will also persist whatever platform configuration (win32 & linux for me) is choosen in the automatic build. If we remove all the os-specific resources sections that are not configured in the automatic build and a user will start the jnlp on a not supported platform, the user see no gui, after jws loading, the rcp exits with a exception. if we don't remove the os-specific resources sections that are not configured and a user will start the jnlp on a not supported platform, the user gets an error from jws that the os-specific resource was not found.
so, maybe it's better to get a jws error than a rcp "silent" error.
I've tested the jnlp with all not supported resources sections (and not available jars) under java 1.4/5.0/6.0. on a supported platform, the rcp starts instead of the not available jars. (i think jws take care about os specific resources only for the running platform).
i hope you understand my explanation!? should i fix it or not?

I have released in HEAD the support to only put in the generated jnlp files the plug-ins matching the configuration being built. However in order to maintain backward compatibility I have not enabled it by default. To enable it, uncomment the property jnlp.configs in the main build.properties.

bug.short_desc: jnlp generation don't resolve binding between feature.xml & their translation files

long_desc.thetext: the generated jnlp files contains the %feature.name & %feature.provider from the MANIFEST.MF which links to the feature.properties file!
Michael, would you know how JNLP deals with translations if they do?
i tink they don't. :-( but the strings from the (default) *.properties file are even better than %feature.name & %feature.provider...
I agree with you. I was just trying to see if there was an easier solution than doing the replacement ourselves :)
Michael, would you have cycles to implement this?
yes, i'll look into it.
That's great thanks. The changes should be localized to the JNLPGenerator class. Let us know if you have any question.

Created an attachment (id=49588) patch to fix the bug
ok, here's the patch to fix the bug

That's great. I glanced through the code and tried it and here are a few comments: - the translation files should be consulted from the most specific to the least one (from en_US, to nothing). - the translation file is not loaded if the feature is not archived - the generation process aborts is there is a problem reading the property file.

> - the translation files should be consulted from the most specific to the least > one (from en_US, to nothing).
i don't think so. cause JNLP don't deal with translations imho it's better to see the default strings instead of a localized version of the one how builds the application (e.g. application is build in spain and the whole world see the spain strings). should i change it to your suggestion anyway?
> - the translation file is not loaded if the feature is not archived
is it possible to create a non archived feature for jnlp?
> - the generation process aborts is there is a problem reading the property > file.
i don't understand your, sorry.

Instead of picking the language from the current locale, it may be better to set the locale on the task and do the lookup the way I proposed. Also we may want to have a flag to disable the translation completly (some people do translation on the fly on the server side).
>is it possible to create a non archived feature for jnlp? I'm sure there is a combination of setup that can make it possible :-) even though the result may not be usable.
> - the generation process aborts is there is a problem reading the property > file. If an exception is thrown when opening or closing the property file stream, then the generation of the jnlp file is aborted.
Created an attachment (id=49688) new patch

> Instead of picking the language from the current locale, it may be better to > set the locale on the task and do the lookup the way I proposed. Also we may > want to have a flag to disable the translation completly (some people do > translation on the fly on the server side).
ok good idea. now you can define the current locale throught the constructor. and the lookup is done in the way you proposed.
> >is it possible to create a non archived feature for jnlp? > I'm sure there is a combination of setup that can make it possible :-) even > though the result may not be usable.
i've added code for non archived features...
> If an exception is thrown when opening or closing the property file stream, > then the generation of the jnlp file is aborted.
oh sorry! my mistake! :-( fixed! :-)

Created an attachment (id=49871) previous patch with formating and minor cleanups
This patch is good. Two minor things: - could you please update the contributors section of the copyrights with the information you want to appear - would you have time to the make the task take an additional parameter to specify the translation language, so that it is not necessarily the one of the running system
fixing the summary

Created an attachment (id=49902) previous patch with updated contributors section
> could you please update the contributors section of the copyrights with the > information you want to appear
done
> would you have time to the make the task take an additional parameter to > specify the translation language, so that it is not necessarily the one of the > running system
maybe, which kind of solution do you like? with a parameter in build.properties?

I'm thinking that it would be a global property set in the build.properties driving the whole build process (see in org.eclipse.pde.build\templates\headless-build\build.properties) like jnlp.codebase and jnlp.j2se are.
This property would always be set on the generated call to the jnlp generator task.

bug.short_desc: Crash after pasting long text in a text editor

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse 3.2
One of my colleagues had a crash today after copying and pasting some very long text from one editor to another. Unfortunately he doesn't remember which editor it was but probably the WTP HTML editor. But the interesting thing is that not any of the traces point to the specific error but to JFace text. Thus, I'm reporting it here.
The error log is very long but it's all related to that error. Looks like Eclipse was in some loop and got unstable et all. After the crash the workspace was corrupted and I had to assist him via VNC to restore it properly. As far as we could tell after that, no project file had been damaged.

Created an attachment (id=46434) Log file from the session
This is the log file from the complete crashed sessions. It all starts with a tiny message.
!MESSAGE "Paste" did not complete normally. Please see the log for more information.

The log says: eclipse.buildId=unknown Are sure it was R3.2?
Marking as INVALID since the initial NPE at: org.eclipse.jface.text.DefaultPositionUpdater.update(line 227) is not possible to have with Eclipse SDK.
Possible reasons: - incorrect install, e.g. copied new build over existing install - JIT bug - bug in another plug-in that sets fOriginalPosition to 'null' (not very likely)

(In reply to comment #2) > The log says: eclipse.buildId=unknown > Are sure it was R3.2?
Yes I am. It's our internal distribution with some branding. :) Note that eclipse.buildId is just a property read from config.ini which is intentionally not set in our distribution.
> Possible reasons: > - incorrect install, e.g. copied new build over existing install > - JIT bug > - bug in another plug-in that sets fOriginalPosition to 'null' (not very > likely)
As reason one can be excluded (I told and force the guys to always rename an existing directory and unzip the distribution into an empty directory) it must be either a JIT bug or a problem in the other editor. :(
Daniel, can you do something to prevent another plug-in from setting fOriginalPosition to null?
>Daniel, can you do something to prevent another plug-in from setting >fOriginalPosition to null? No, it is protected for performance reasons.
*** Bug 180728 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

But if some other code is indeed setting fOriginalPosition to null, wouldn't an additional guard which reinitializes fOriginalPosition, if needed, be a working quick fix?
i.e. change: > fOriginalPosition.offset= fPosition.offset;
to: > if (fOriginalPosition == null) > fOriginalPosition = new Position(0, 0); > fOriginalPosition.offset= fPosition.offset; (though moving the check above the for loop would probably be better)
in: org.eclipse.jface.text.DefaultPositionUpdater.update(DefaultPositionUpdater.java:233)
And fPosition can't be null here either? Are these values ever accessed concurrently by multiple threads?
We don't add guards if you don't know why the NPE happens. This just hides an error at some other place.

Ok, I was finally able to catch the exception in a debugger run.
It seems as if it is not fOriginalPosition that is null, but one of the elements of the Position array which is returned by org.eclipse.jface.text.IDocument#getPositions(java.lang.String).
I don't quite see how that could have happened though. If I understand correctly, there shouldn't be any concurrency issues when using a SynchronizableDocument. But a race condition is the only explanation which I can come up with right now though. However, when looking at the SynchronizableDocument implementation it will only synchronise access, if there exists a lockObject. But in this stack dump, lockObject is null. Which means that no synchronisation code is executed.
If the execution of AbstractDocument's org.eclipse.jface.text.IDocument#getPositions(java.lang.String) implementation would be interrupted between these two lines
> Position[] positions= new Position[c.size()]; > c.toArray(positions);
by another thread which removed an element from the positions list for that position category, that would result in the failure described in this bug report.
So is the real defect here that the text editor fails to correctly set a lock object for the document then?
Here is some of the data which I extracted from the debugger. Unfortunately when catching an NPE it stops at the end of the method, and the Position array value is thus no longer accessible. I tried using a conditional breakpoint but it was way too slow (~30sec delay per key press) to be of any use.

>I've written a Junit4 test case which reproduces the failure on my system (it >may take a long time, it is basically a large number of edits with random >delays). Good, that will help us to reproduce the bug then. Please attach it here. Also, "long time" depends on your view on things - are we talking about seconds or hours?

Created an attachment (id=79969) JUnit4 test case which reproduces the failure on my system - READ THE COMMENT
This is a small plugin project which contains a JUnit4 test case that reproduces the failure on my system.
Notes: - English (could be any language but German) spell checking needs to be enabled (you need to see the red lines below most of the words in the text) - The defect is a race condition. The test case tries to create the failure condition by doing an endless number of edits with random delays. On my system it can take between one second and a couple of hours to reproduce the failure. Most of the time I get a failure within the first 15 minutes though. - This was tested on a dual-core system. Things might be different on a single-core system.

Another note about the test case.
I just tried it with 3.3.1 (M20070921-1145) and it will be very unlikely to reproduce the bug on such a system because the number of spellcheck suggestions is now limited.
However, if the limits on the spelling preferences page are increased as much as possible, the test case will still reproduce the issue.

3.3.1.1 still has this issue.
I'd suggest changing the status of this entry from RESOLVED to REOPENED.
The problem here is that a file opened in a TextEditor will lead to a SynchronizableDocument which does not have its lock object initialised.
I am not familiar with the IDocumentProvider code base but it seems that for a java file, CompilationUnitDocumentProvider.createFileInfo(Object) calls TextFileDocumentProvider.setUpSynchronization(FileInfo) which in turn calls SynchronizableDocument.setLockObject(Object).
For a text file on the other hand, TextFileDocumentProvider.createFileInfo(Object) never calls TextFileDocumentProvider.setUpSynchronization(FileInfo) and thus SynchronizableDocument.setLockObject(Object) is never called.
Is there any reason why a text document should not be synchronised? As CompilationUnitDocumentProvider extends TextFileDocumentProvider, changing this in TextFileDocumentProvider might be a bit problematic. But a new sub-class, i.e. SynchronizableTextFileDocumentProvider, could be used for the TextEditor, couldn't it?
I understand that this might not be high on the priority list. However, we're still experiencing multiple TextEditor crashes per day, which are most likely all caused by the fact that the documents are not being synchronised.
Thanks a lot.
MfG H. Meyer

I got this too today:
1. Open text editor with 'Faust - Der Tragoedie erster Teil' 2. Enable spell checking with English dict 3. Set max spell errors to 9999 4. Show spelling errors in vertical ruler (and only there) 5. Now start typing, saving, typing new lines, saving, ... like a maniac for a few seconds, exception is drown and editor is unusable
Also got this: java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 9469, Size: 9469 at java.util.ArrayList.RangeCheck(ArrayList.java:546) at java.util.ArrayList.get(ArrayList.java:321) at org.eclipse.jface.text.AbstractDocument.removePosition(AbstractDocument.java:1003) at org.eclipse.core.internal.filebuffers.SynchronizableDocument.removePosition(SynchronizableDocument.java:203) at org.eclipse.jface.text.AbstractDocument.removePosition(AbstractDocument.java:1015) at org.eclipse.jface.text.TextViewer.setMark(TextViewer.java:4591) at org.eclipse.ui.texteditor.IncrementalFindTarget.beginSession(IncrementalFindTarget.java:305) at org.eclipse.ui.texteditor.IncrementalFindAction.run(IncrementalFindAction.java:100)
Looks like we have a synchronization issue
*** Bug 211509 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

(In reply to comment #26) > *** Bug 211509 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Hi Daniel
Reading what the other had seen on their cases, i try to edit other program, shorter than the one how has the issue (This one has more than 4000 line of code) and let me work normally, then i disable the spell cheking function on the editor, a went back to the firsto program and let me work as well, i think maybe the spell cheking function when detects too many words mispelled, can handle it and blocks the editor.
For now i can work like this, because i don't need the spell cheking function, (my work is in cobol and i dont have a compiler on my pc).
Thanks for the support, if you find some way of fix this, please let me know.
Thanks again
Ivn Rojas

bug.short_desc: [api] IPropertyType should have a "read-only" setting

long_desc.thetext: It should be possible to define properties as "read-only" in order to avoid users from modifying them in the ServicesForm or ConnectorServicesForm.
I believe we should have this be an attribute of IProperty and not IPropertyType. Comments?

To be honest, I think that both make sense somehow.
The original intent was for properties like an "Object Type" that can never be changed by a user, because an object is an object and cannot ever change its type. It's a read-only property that is shown for information only.
But then you are right, there are also properties that are theoretically editable (like the name of an object, for instance) but cannot be edited at a given time - either because they are locked, or a file system is read-only, or a dialog just does not support editing.
My feeling is that for the latter case, typically, it's an all-or-nothing issue: either all those properties which are editable in principle can also be edited (because the file system allows it etc) or none can be edited.
Therefore I think that IProperty.setReadOnly() is of less value than IPropertyType.setReadOnly().

Types have typically been immutable. This has the pragmatic side effect of allowing singleton instances to be shared. Having a settable read-only attribute would break this unless we introduce new singletons for the read-only types.
Another thought - by "read-only" you don't want to disallow the setting of a property value in the IProperty protocol, you just want to have a means of disallowing editing in a dialog, correct?
Added the read-only attribute to IProperty which is needed in any case. Please re-open if this is really desired for IPropertyType as well.

bug.short_desc: Adpot ICU4J APIs

long_desc.thetext:
From bug 136189 comment #1
-----------
The webdav project can adopt ICU4J in the following places:
org.eclipse.webdav.client.Policy - use ICU's MessageFormat org.eclipse.webdav.internal.Policy - use ICU's MessageFormat org.eclipse.webdav.internal.kernel.Policy - use ICU's MessageFormat instead of java.text org.eclipse.webdav.internal.kernel.utils.DateTime - use ICU's SimpleDateFormat, Calendar, TimeZone

We need to determine how we want to proceed here. Currently the WebDAV plug-in is structured in a way such that it can be used outside of an OSGi environment; just as a JAR in a Java application.
Perhaps the best thing to do is: - create an optional dependancy - have conditional code which tries to load the appropriate class and if that doesn't work then we default to Java class library behaviour
The optional dependancy could be on icu4j or on osgi (NLS class).
See also bug 18558 which talks about adding progress monitor cancellation to the APIs. If this bug goes forward, it would add a non-optional dependancy on equinox.common and osgi.
This component is no longer being actively developed. We encourage users to investigate the capabilities of the Eclipse Web Tools Project.

bug.short_desc: Comments alone on a line leave empty lines in the output

long_desc.thetext:
If you put a comment such as
<%-- a comment --%>
in a template, then a new line is emitted when template is executed.
But, if you do something like:
<% /* a comment */ %>
no new line is emitted (although the generated Java code includes /* a comment */
JET has rules for removing undesireable whitespace after XML tags and Java elements, but not comments. It should have rules for comments, too.
Some previous bugs on whitespace/new line stripping:
bug 131380 bug 136161

In addition to comments alone on a line, consideration to comments that share a line with another element should be considered:
<c:if test="..."> <%-- a comment --%>
and <%-- a comment --%> <%-- another comment --%>
In both these cases, it can be argued that whitespace, including new line should be stripped. But in attempting to do so, care must be taken not to repeat bug 316161.

Whitespace will be stripped around a comment only if it is the only element on a line. This is consistent with line stripping of other elements.
Changes committed to CVS.
Fixed in build 0.7.1 M200608030817

bug.short_desc: [Help] keyword index has broken links to ignoredTOCS topics

long_desc.thetext:
If a TOC is ignored using the plugin_customization.ini file's ignoredTOCS property, and if the topics it would wire in have index entries associated with them, then the index's links to those topics are broken (because, of course, the topics shouldn't be appearing because they've been ignored).
This is tricky, because other than the fact that they're linking to the same topic(s), there's no direct correlation between the TOC and the index. They might not even be in the same plug-in, in theory.
This is pretty critical to us, as we like to ignore contributions that are out of scope of our users (rather than bury them), but we are also expecting to use the index extensively.
Just to confirm the behavior we want: If a keyword points to a topic which is in one of the ignoredTocs, it will simply not appear in the list of keywords. Correct?

Almost. If that topic also appears in a different TOC that's not ignored, we'd want the index entry to show (topics can be linked to from multiple TOCs). If an index entry links to a topic, and ALL the TOCs that link to that topic are ignored (the topic appears nowhere in the nav tree), then we don't want to see the index entry.
Fixed in both HEAD and 3.2.1 branch.

This fix has caused a 15% drop in 'build TOC' performance test. Normally I would be willing to swallow this drop if it made help behave as specified, but here it seems to me that we are paying the TOC price for the keyword index (which some products may not have). For example, Eclipse currently does not have it.
Is there a way to delay this additional processing until the user has requested keyboard index for the first time?
Let's track the performance regression in bug 157184.

The fix for this is causing too many problems in 3.3 with performance and I believe we need a different approach.
The problem is that there is a dependency between index and toc, and I cannot show a single keyword (or even the keyword index tab) until I have fully processed the entire toc, and this partially defeats the purpose of the new deferred-loading toc view that Chris is developing.
Kari, please inform the necessary teams that for 3.3, wherever you ignore a toc using ignoredTOCS, you must do the same for the corresponding keyword index, using ignoredIndexes which has the same format except it points to index files. In fact this option was available in 3.2.1 but I did not see it as it wasn't documented. I have added the docs in 3.3. Apologies for the flip flop.

Fair enough. This actually means I don't have to create a new bug reporting that the fix wasn't working for Linux. Unless you want me to at least report that problem on 3.2.1 (I'll assume not, unless you tell me so).
Thanks.

bug.short_desc: Remote Monitor can schedule refresh jobs before pending jobs are finished

long_desc.thetext:
If the Remote Monitor is used for polling a very slow system, and refresh rate is set to 5 seconds, refresh jobs are scheduled every 5 seconds regardless if the previous refresh job has been completed or not.
A new refresh job schould be scheduled only (n seconds) after the previous one has been completed.
I've added a wait() to ensure the poll query job completes before the next interval is calculated and a query is run.

bug.short_desc: Remote Monitor makes the System View unusable

long_desc.thetext:
Set Preferences > Remote Systems > Use Deferred Queries = true.
When the Remote Monitor is used to poll a very slow system, and refresh rate is set to 5 seconds, refresh jobs are scheduled very frequently.
While a remote monitor's refresh job is running, the RSE Tree only shows "Pending..." so the view elements are not usable. As soon as the result of the query gets visible, "Pending..." is shown again.
The Remote Monitor should leave the old view contents intact until its new results are available from the remote system. Only then, the old data should be replaced with the new one.
Dave can you check if this is fixed by 1.0M5?

The monitor view is driven by SystemDeferredTableTreeContentManager which extends DeferredTreeContentManager. DeferredTreeContentManager is responsible for creating the "Pending..." item and then collecting results to show in the view. I'm not sure if we should be interfering with that standard Eclipse behaviour.
Any thoughts about this?
Looking ata the view here again and I really don't see any problems. I'm going to mark it as fixed - feel free to reopen if you still see a problem.

The problem is in the interaction of the two views. The monitor is causing an automatic refresh of the Systems View at the point of the monitor. If I monitor the actual host (instead of a folder) the "pending..." appears and the whole tree collapses back to its first level. This makes it very difficult to navigate the tree while a monitor is running since the tree is constantly being refreshed.
Both the monitor and the system view are driven from the same model so it may not be possible to dissociate the monitor from the view without some work. I believe folks would see the automatic refresh of the tree when the monitor refreshes as unnatural. Would it be possible or make sense to refresh a copy of a section of the model in the viewer - or perhaps use a filter as a root object that is not visible in the tree?
Reopening - I recommend that this be deferred for some continuing discussion on how monitors should work.

Agree -> setting target milestone 2.0
My personal feeling is that the refresh queries from the remote monitor should not show a "pending..." message while they are ongoing. Once the data has arrived from the query, the model (and tree) should be updated without destroying existing selection.

One thing that could simplify this problem a bit would be to turn the Remote Monitor back into a table rather than a table-tree. For the most part the value of this view lies in it's use as table, however others may see the tree aspect of this as an important (albeit problematic) bonus. Any thoughts on that?

I've changed the monitor back from a table-tree to a table since the value of this view is mostly in it's table capabilities. Although this doesn't probably doesn't address the SystemView issue described, it does reduce some of the complexity issues of the monitor.
moving to m6 to look at later
deferring to m7 since it does not seem API is affected
*** Bug 161431 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

There is little we can do in the RSE framework to fix this, as long as the client subsystems use deferred jobs and the DeferredTreeContentManager. Deferring to after 2.0.
The DeferredTreeContentManager is responsible for collapsing tree nodes in order to refresh them. While this is done, the tree node is unusable. The problem might be alleviated slightly when the REFRESH events do a better job maintaining the current selection and expand state, as discussed on bug #173042.
Clients can work around this as follows: 1. Have an ISystemViewElementAdapter with supportsDeferredQueries==false 2. Have ISystemViewElementAdapter#getChildren() always return local (cached) model objects 3. Listen to ISystemResourceChangeEvents.REFRESH* events 3a. When a refresh event is received, perform an asynchronous retrieval of data from the remote side, with a callback 3b. When the callback is received, update the local (cached) model and send a REFRESH event that is a subclass of the normal refresh event 3c. Have step (3a) distinguish the special local refresh event from the RSE one, and do not perform the asynchrous retrieval in this case.
In other words, the client doesn't use the RSE deferred query / job mechanism but rather performs asynchrouns remote queries itself.

Actually, hacking this up might work as follows:
* In SystemView.getContextObject(TreeItem), extend the IContextObject to also contain the TreeItem referring to the requested parent.
* In SystemDeferredTreeContentManager.getChildren() get the TreeItem out of the IContextObject in order to get the currently displayed children. Instead of just returning the pendingAdapter, return an array of pendingAdapter AND the existing children, and remember the list of existing children.
* At the callback when the deferred getter job returns, Perform a refresh of the remembered old list of children against the new list of children; removing, adding, updating properties where needed. The absoluteName may be needed to do this properly. Also, for those TreeItem children that were expanded at the time of refresh, another deferred job needs to be started now. Finally, when all previously expanded members are returned, apply the selection that was remembered at the very beginning.
Basically, this idea applies a similar algorithm as was in place in the SystemView at the time when no deferred queries were supported. Note that with the Local files subsystem, the case of non-deferred-queries can still be tried out: it retains selection and expand state in many more cases.
Anyways, I'm not pushing this fix forward any more, since at Wind River we're using the async query method described in comment #12 so it's not so much of an issue for us. A fix for this might be considered for 2.0.1.

bug.short_desc: problem by debugger start

long_desc.thetext:
the konfiguration is: Windows2000, Eclipse 3.2.0, CDT 3.1.0, arm-elf-gdb, remote target, serial connection. (GDB uses command file on order to start the debug session. It works OK with Eclipse 3.1.2 and CDT 3.0.2.)

bug.short_desc: Allow pluggable strategies to resolve issue urls from VCS comments

long_desc.thetext: Users are often using issue numbers in VCS comments when resolving issues. Mylar should allow connector plugins to contribute additional text mining strategies for autoresolving issue numbers and their repositories from the commit comments.

Created an attachment (id=46447) Example of CVS comments in sync view
Example of CVS comments in sync view used by Spring team. Note Jira issue numbers referenced up there.

I'm thinking that for now we 'require' that there be some prefix before the task's key. For JIRA I've made the prefix be "issue SPR-2227". While this has the benefit of being clear and consistent without much overhead, the cost of is that we do't correctly hyperlink reports from committers not using this convention, and in some cases it is be possible to resolve those (e.g. the first part of every project, e.g. "SPR-" on a JIRA server could be cached locally). Not likely we'll have time to do the latter for 1.0 so marking as helpwanted.
Mik, requiring "issue" prefix for Jira would be a huge limitation. I can't possible tell somebody whom project I monitor how his comments should look like.

So what you're saying is that seeing just the issue ID alone is a common occurrence? I'm not sure if we have all of the project prefixes from JIRA Core Services or if it's even something that JIRA exposes. If it does this should be doable, and the extensible matching seems like a good idea so I'm tentatively scheduling this for 1.0. But since it's not clear that we'll be able to prioritize it I'm leaving it as 'helpwanted' for now.
Deferring, although Eugene, you may have made some progress on this already with ILinkedTaskInfo?

(In reply to comment #6) > Deferring, although Eugene, you may have made some progress on this already > with ILinkedTaskInfo?
Yep. It is "accidentally" fixed.
JiraRepositoryConnector.getTaskIdsFromComment() provide custom strategy to parse repository-specific links.
That is what original report was requesting. So, I basically ended up implementing it myself...
I suspected that :)

attachment.desc: Example of CVS comments in sync view

bug.short_desc: "Do not echo input" - missing

long_desc.thetext:
Hi,
i use eclipse 3.2 with birt 2.1 and report engine 2.1.
When i design a report with the birt-eclipse-designer, i can create a TextBox with "Do not echo input" (e.g. for password input). This works fine in birt-preview. But how can i get the "Do not echo input" flag from report engine? The 2 relevant classes are "IGetParameterDefinitionTask" (e.g. getting default value there) and "IScalarParameterDefn". But there are no methods to get the "Do not echo input" flag.
Is there a magic trick to get these flag in the report engine? Is these flag missing?
Best regrads
-- orkus
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 150917 ***

bug.short_desc: Variables created with default initializations

long_desc.thetext:
When a variable is added to a visual component, it is added to the code and initialized with a default value, which is just extra code and just extra runtime execution when the class is constructed.
For example, I added a JTextArea, m_srcObjLabel. And the code that created is:
private JLabel m_srcObjLabel = null;
There's no reason to assign null, since null is going to get assigned to it automatically anyway.

bug.short_desc: [JUnit] JUNIT Source Attachment location setting not future proof

long_desc.thetext:
Configure Build Path -> Libaries [tab] -> Add Libraries -> Select "JUnit"
The configured Source Attachment is not using JUNIT_SRC_HOME/junitsrc.zip
The problem with this is when you use Eclipse 3.1 and Add the Library from there. Then upgrade to Eclipse 3.2, the path for the source attachment location stays fixed to:
ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip
which is not correct for Eclipse 3.2, it should not resolve to:
ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.2.0.v20060609m-F7snq1fxia-Z4XP/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip
By using the JUNIT_SRC_HOME/junitsrc.zip this problem can be fixed.
I have no idea how you plan on resolving the problem of shipping JUnit 3.8.1 and 4.1.0 as builtins. I think the variable redirection is a good idea, but you still need to resolve which version of JUnit you should be pointing to on a project by project basis.
Related bugs: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=138877

I'd be happy if you have simple reproducble steps to explain this. In 3.2 we added the JUnit container (Build Path -> Libaries -> Add Libraries -> "JUnit") which hides all source attachment paths from you. In 3.1 we only have the class path variables JUNIT_HOME and JUNIT_SRC_HOME. (Build Path -> Libaries -> Add Variable)
I have no idea who configured ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip. Can you explain?

Well if from 3.2 I use the steps:
Configure Build Path -> Libaries [tab] -> Add Libraries -> Select "JUnit"
I get configured:
JUNIT 3.8.1 junit.jar: /opt/eclipse_3.2_WTP1.5/plugins/org.junit_3.8.1 Source Attachment: /opt/eclipse_3.2_WTP1.5/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.2.0.v20060609m-F7snq1fxia-Z4XP/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip
I am not allowed to edit the junit.jar entry line but thats fine as I have never experienced problems during upgrade of finding the class JAR. The problem has been with the source attachment.
But I can edit the Source Attachment by selecting it and clicking Edit.
If I do that I can see the path here does not use JUNIT_SRC_HOME but a hardwired fully qualify path, which was valid at the time I used the UI wizard to add it but may not be valid after I upgrade the platform.
So in the future when I expect to upgrade to Eclipse 3.3/3.4 or 4.0 that path remains set to the eclipse 3.2 location which will be incorrect after I upgrade.
But I think this entry should have been configured by the UI Wizard to be JUNIT_SRC_HOME/junitsrc.zip.

Infact there appears to be 2 scheme to add JUnit, if I compare doing the operation on my 3.2 today to what my historical project have configured.
One scheme using the wizard giving a Libraries reference of: "Junit 3.8.1" and another one way that gives a reference of JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar.
The new format appear to work fine, but the original problem here was when upgrading from 3.1 using the JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar which was added by some wizard in the past its source attachment does not use JUNIT_SRC_HOME. When its clear when going in an manually fixing it a variable is allowed in that box.
I'm pretty sure it was a wizard that added the JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar to the build paths of my project, since I would not have been savvy enough to have setup the Source Attachment part if I had of done this manually.
The resulting problem then meant the locate Source File function considered missing source attachments as fatal error and that functionatly stopped working. Bug #138877.
Fragment of my .classpath for JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar project:
<classpathentry sourcepath="ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip" kind="var" path="JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar"/>
Then after manually fixing:
<classpathentry sourcepath="/JUNIT_SRC_HOME/junitsrc.zip" kind="var" path="JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar"/>
Maybe the old wizard which added it is now obsolete with the new method that allows Junit 3.8.1 and 4.0.x to co-exist.

The JUnit container has the advantage that it recomputes the actual location of the source attachment on every startup. No source attachment location hardcoded.
As said, I don't know who added the JUNIT_HOME. Maybe we had a bug in erlier versions. The current version only adds containers. I guess manually fixing is the way to go, or update to the new container, that's even better.
I'm marking this as WORKSFORME, ok?

Yes fine by me if the new containers scheme is now the default way. Maybe this serves as a placeholder for others to fix when upgrading to 3.2.
The fix is:
* Remove the JUNIT_HOME from the libraries list in the build path Remove button.
* Re-add it with the Add Libraries, so that it uses the new container scheme.

bug.short_desc: [hashcode/equals] equal and hashcode should use acessors instead of the fields directly

long_desc.thetext: The generated equals and hascode methods could use accessors instead of fields directly.
Moving to JDT UI

Why would it be better to use the accessors? Such an accessor could have a side effect (for example through lazy initialization), not something equals should do.
No plans for this, but please add your reasons here, maybe I'm wrong.

"for example through lazy initialization" this is exactly the reason for example a (lazy)proxy like a cglib proxy doesnt have an internal state and this.propertyName doesnt mean anything to it but this.getPropertyName() forwards the call to real object .
I am not saying current implementation is faulty but user should be given an option of generating these methods through accessors too ( may a prefernce setting or something ).

Sorry I'm not conviced. Unless we get more requests for this, no plans to offer such an option. It is always recommended to review the result of equals or equals and fixing the code to use getters is easy to do.

bug.short_desc: [Editor] problems adding elements and attributes with XML Schema Editor

long_desc.thetext:
Tried to use the xml schema tool (File -> New -> Other -> XML -> XML Schema) to create a schema, ran into some problems:
1. There is no option to add <any> element from design view 2. There is no option to add <any attribute> for Attributes design view. 3. Right clicking on a type -> Add attribute, the tool will try to change the name of the type, but not create the new attribute using the name I specify. For example, I needs to create an attribute named "address", the tool creates an attribute named as "NewAttribute1". 4. The same issue with the "Add element" option for a type.
Kenneth, in which part of the UI were you right-clicking to add the attribute and elements?

1. You can add an any element off of the sequence node. We are working on reorganizing the Add actions. 2. You can add an anyAttribute from a complex type's context menu 3. I know that we had a problem adding a global attribute from the schema view, and this bug was fixed in 1.5.1. But from a type, it should be working from the design view. 4. If both 3 and 4 are done from the outline view, then it's WAD. You'll have to refactor or use the properties view to rename.

changing the summary to make it more meaningful
I'm not sure I understand the problem here. Kenneth can you be more explicit about which views you are using and how you are attempting to rename things?
Other than the fact that we bury the add 'any element' menu item I don't view these as bugs (but maybe I'm not understanding the issue properly).

bug.short_desc: JNDI and Username-Password

long_desc.thetext:
As noted in the newsgroup thread (JNDI and Username-Password, Mon, 10 Jul 2006 15:21:03 +0200), the JNDI configuration of a data source does not work if the configured JDBC username in the report design is incorrect.
Linda Chan suggested making the username and password parameters to the report. This is an unacceptable and dangerous security risk; especially if one is using the web report viewer that displays all parameters in the URL.
The report engine needs to be fixed to query for the username and password from the JNDI configuration (if configured) each time the report is executed. By default, the JNDI configuration should take precedence over the configured username and password.

>> query for the username and password from the JNDI configuration (if configured)
This is not feasible. Each JNDI resource factory may have its own variation of vendor-specific JNDI configuration. BIRT is vendor-neutral.
Mapping an username and password to a report parameter does not mean you have to show any hard-coded values for them. Their default values can be empty strings. If user does not enter any value, the default JNDI configuration get used (as described in the newsgroup thread). Furthermore, you can also hide a report parameter, if you do not want to show it in certain deployment environments.
See this newsgroup thread for more info. news://news.eclipse.org/44B6C233.E0430E19%40actuate.com

bug.short_desc: ExtendedDataElement children are not shown in Log View

long_desc.thetext:
When importing a log file which has ExtendedDataElements containing children, the children are not shown in the Properties pane of the Log View. I'll attach a sample CommonBaseEvent XML log file that contains children ExtendedDataElements. I have debugged this to confirm that the model contains the children. The problem is the view is not showing them.
I was using the TPTP 4.2 Callisto release driver to reproduce this.

Created an attachment (id=46450) Sample CommonBaseEvent XML log file with children ExtendedDataElements
The first ExtendedDataElement with name "level" contains children that are not shown in the view.
Under investigation for 4.2.1; if this is a valid problem we should ask approval to be included in 4.2.1
This is a valid problem. I have been able to reproduce the bug as described below. I am working on solving it now.

Created an attachment (id=46763) patch for bugzilla_150966
Outputs EDE information in the form: level |- Name level |- Type noValue |- Hexvalue |- Values |- Children |- name |- Name name |- Type string |- Hexvalue |- Values |- Audit |- Children |- value |- Name value |- Type int |- Hexvalue |- Values |- 850 |- Children
Patch checked in

attachment.desc: Sample CommonBaseEvent XML log file with children ExtendedDataElements

bug.short_desc: [Help] Setting a Help Server requires restart

long_desc.thetext:
As i had problems with my Help View (HTTP 500 - Internal server error), I set the Help Server to be the actual IP address of the PC: Window -> Preferences... -> Help -> Help Server -> Host name or IP addressm -> MY_IP_ADDR
I pushed Apply and OK but the change only took effect after shutting eclipse down and restart. This is very problematic when i want to use Help after i launch a separate eclipse application to test my plugin.
If this isn't covered by UA please punt it back...

Note, if you set it before opening help you don't have to restart. You only need to restart if the help server is already started.
I would actually be more interested in why it's not working for you. Is there anything logged to <workspace>/.metadata/.log ?

Nothing suspicious on the log. It happens to me only from within my University workstation (at home everything works just fine). The university system team claim there is no firewall on the stations, Any ideas?
You are right about applying the change before starting the Help Server, this allows me to bypass the problem but I think there is something more fundamental here - when i want to test a plugin using "Launch an Eclipse application" from the plugin overview screen - the child eclipse does not include the Help Server IP address of the parent application. Shouldn't a child application follow parent configuration?

>Shouldn't a child application follow parent configuration?
Actually in general it shouldn't. If you're developing, say, an e-mail client with the eclipse SDK, you wouldn't want your e-mail client to start behaving like the SDK you're developing it with. You would want the 'child' application to work the same way it would were it built and launched separately, otherwise you couldn't properly test it this way.
In Eclipse 3.3 we removed the server preference page so this bug no longer applies.

I have not been able to reproduce this on a plain install of the eclipse SDK running with Sun 1.5.0_07 and all of the mentioned vmargs. I've been testing on gtk 2.8.18. Does the crash still occur if you use other VMs or is this strictly an issue on Sun 1.5.0_07?

I also managed to get it to crash with 1.4.2_10. After adjusting the JVM args, it seems to be stable. Here is the new list:
/opt/eclipse-3.2/eclipse -vmargs -Dsun.java2d.opengl=true -Dswing.aatext=true -client -Xms256m -Xmx256m -Xss256k -Xverify:none -XX:NewRatio=2 -XX:NewSize=128m -XX:SurvivorRatio=16 -XX:PermSize=96m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m -XX:+DisableExplicitGC -XX:+UseLargePages -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC -XX:+CMSPermGenSweepingEnabled -XX:+CMSClassUnloadingEnabled -XX:+CMSPermGenSweepingEnabled -XX:+CMSIncrementalMode -XX:+CMSIncrementalPacing -XX:CMSIncrementalDutyCycleMin=0 -XX:CMSIncrementalDutyCycle=10
I think it may have been a stack space issue.
We're using gtk+-2.8.19.

re: comment 11 That is quite possible, as the trace in comment 9 does not indicate an swt issue. In 3.2 there have been problems with sun vm users running out of permgen space (see bug 92250). I don't think there's anything for swt to do here.
Ok, mark it as a dup of the famous permgen bug or close it. Note that althougth the bug is marked OS:Linux-GTK, comment #9 contains a VM dump with references to Windows DLLSs, which is confusing.

I'm pretty certain it was stack space based on the last gdb session I ran, which was pretty obvious. :) I increased the stack and it was fine. The heap changes were for WST and unrelated. The Windows VM dump is to illustrate that it was happening not only on the Linux JVM.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 92250 ***

bug.short_desc: store and present repository labels in addition to URLs

long_desc.thetext: Repository label is not saved for Bugzilla and Jira, so I could not use custom label there.
*** Bug 153599 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

We need to make Labels more consistent--currently they do not surface properly in the UI. For the time being to avoid confusion I have changed "Label/template" to "Template" on the repository settings page.
Created an attachment (id=48787) mylar/context/zip
Mik, I really missing ability to define labels and see them on repository selection dialogs. Those web links are quite difficult to tell apart from each other...
Yes, let's use this bug report to fix that...
By the way, I still think it provider icons should be shown on repository instances... along with those labels.
Yes, we just had that same discussion, and we'll probably make them bottom-right-hand-corner overlays since there is plenty of room. Hard for icons like Bugzilla but I'll give it another whirl.

Shall we go with an additional 'label' field in the Task Repository Settings page? Mixing the label and template selection field may be over complicated. In the Task Repositories View my first thought is that we present the respective repository icon (with 'blue bin' overlay) followed by the user provided label and make the actual url available via the mouse over tooltip. Thoughts?

We could move template selection into the url field.
As of label, I don't think it is necessary to show the url if label is not empty. If user want to see url he can just put it into the label.

Update: TaskRepository view shows branding icon followed by label (if label doesn't exist it displays the url). Templates can be selected from server combo which replaces the url with template.url and the label with template.label.
Created an attachment (id=49572) mylar/context/zip

I think the old task repositories view that did not have columns looked a lot better and was "more intuitive" as it somewhat resembled the CVS/SVN repositories view.
I noticed that repositories do not have labels anymore when using wizards that require repository selection such as the new query wizard.

I agree with Steffen--we're not getting that much out of the columns and they do add substantial visual complexity. Also, getting rid of the column will make it easier for this to become a common navigator view if needed.
Rob: if you get rid of the additional column the default label provider on the tree will do the right thing and show the label if there is one.
Fixed.

bug.short_desc: Progress Monitor not handled correctly during launch

long_desc.thetext:
I am trying to create a command-line launch command in our proprietary command-line tool. The command must be synchronized so that the next command is not allowed to start until the launch is complete. This is critical for writing scripts.
The mechanism I have to synchronize my command is an IProgressMonitor callback object, which I pass into:
org.eclipse.debug.core/src/org/eclipse/debug/internal/core/ LaunchConfiguration.launch()
The problem is I am getting two pairs of calls to IProgressMonitor.beginTask() and IProgressMonitor.done(). There are also some problems related to work not being reported properly.
The following white paper gives tips on how to do this properly, namely that there can be one and only one pair of beginTask() and done():
http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-Progress-Monitors/article.html
I have a proposed fix which I will post once we have reviewed it internally.

Another thing, the comment for IProgressMonitor.internalWorked() does not match the behavior I am seeing. The comment implies that it should basically be ignored, but in fact, for the work units to work correctly, it appears that internalWorked() is being called in some cases where worked() would otherwise be expected. I suspect this is because of SubProgressMonitor, though I have not investigated. In fact, I have implemented internalWorked() with a simple call to worked().
It would be nice to update the comments in IProgressMonitor to fix this problem as well as to add more usage info as described in the white paper.
Created an attachment (id=47365) Proposed fix.

updated progress monitoring for launching.
It seems that we were passing the original parent monitor into launchdelegate.launch(..), which was then further calling beginTask on it (even though it had already started)
Also we only want to start the task in the launch method if the monitor needs to be created.

see LaunchConfiguration.launch(...)
please verify Curtis W
Verified

Thanks, this works much better. I do wonder though about the placement of the final monitor.done(). Wouldn't it be a better design to place it at the level of the monitor.beginTask() as is shown in the Eclipse Article referenced previously? Also, it should be placed in a finally clause to make certain that it always gets called.

You are right Tom, if the launch method bombs at any point before we have a chance to cancel or otherwise the done method could not get called at all.
changed in HEAD added try...finally to build and launch, and added in boolean check to LaunchConfiguraiton.launch(...) to see if the monitor was created locally and needs to be closed locally.

bug.short_desc: Product Export does not create a working package for gtk-linux

long_desc.thetext:
When using 3.2.0 Build M20060629-1905, the package generated by the product export in the UI does not work for gtk linux. This is also true if the package is generated in a headless manner via productBuild.xml.
It does not seem to matter what host platform is used to build the package...building on windows or linux (FC4) creates an unusable package. After exporting the product, everything seems fine, however when you attempt to run the native launcher, the initial splash screen for the product appears, but then eclipse exits with a dialogue pointing to a log file. The log file states that product-specific classes cannot be found. There is also mention of an SWTError class that cannot be found. This class resides in org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86_3.2.0.v3232m.jar, which is not included in the exported product. The applcation-specific classes do exist under the plugin directory. When exporting to win32, the generated package works fine.

Is the org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86 plugin listed in your .product file, or included in a feature that is in the .product file? Product export only includes plugins referenced from the .product file. Platform specific fragments must be included.

Adding the gtk-linux jar cleared up some of the initial error. However, there is now a different error. Specifically:
!SESSION 2006-06-22 00:48:42.649 ----------------------------------------------- eclipse.buildId=unknown java.version=1.5.0_07 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=motif, NL=en_US Command-line arguments: -consoleLog -debug
!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi 2 0 2006-06-22 00:48:44.560 !MESSAGE The following is a complete list of bundles which are not resolved, see the prior log entry for the root cause if it exists: !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.osgi 2 0 2006-06-22 00:48:44.560 !MESSAGE Bundle initial@reference:file:plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86_3.2.0.v3232m.jar/ [26] was not resolved. !SUBENTRY 2 org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86 2 0 2006-06-22 00:48:44.561 !MESSAGE Platform filter did not match: (& (osgi.ws=gtk) (osgi.os=linux) (osgi.arch=x86)) !SUBENTRY 2 org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86 2 0 2006-06-22 00:48:44.562 !MESSAGE Missing Constraint: Fragment-Host: org.eclipse.swt; bundle-version="[3.0.0,4.0.0)"
I assume there are still some platform-specific fragments/plugins that need to be added. Is this correct? If so, how do I determine what needs to be added?

If your product is based on plugins, there is an "Add Required Plug-ins" button in the product editor. If it is based on features, I'm not sure that there is an automated way to do it.
Note however, from what you posted, you appear to be running on motif: BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=motif, NL=en_US
Which would be the reason the org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86 didn't resolve: !MESSAGE Platform filter did not match: (& (osgi.ws=gtk) (osgi.os=linux) (osgi.arch=x86))
If you are trying to export cross platform, make sure you have the delta pack installed and check "Export for multiple platforms" in the export wizard to choose the platform.

Your suggestions corrected the problem. The motif problem happend when I changed the desktop theme to bluecurve since clearlooks was not supported by the gtk engine. In summary, my problems were caused by not understanding the required steps for exporting to multiple platforms. I have been focused during the past few days on getting multiple platforms built automatically via ANT (not a small feat I might add) and thus I was not paying much attention to the options available in the GUI. What was not clear to me is that different steps are required depending on if you are using the PDE UI to export to linux or windows. When running on windows, you can successfully export to windows without adding platform-specific modules to your product. If you are running on linux, a platform export to linux will not produce any errors, but the generated package will not run unless you first add the platform-specific modules via the Add-Required-Plugins button. It seems that windows is given special treatment since you don't have to do anything extra to get a working exported product, but with Linux, and possbily other platforms, you do.
It seems that the problems here have been resolved.

bug.short_desc: Using static instrumentation of a JAR via the ARM Generic Probe causes problems with vanilla ARM implementation

long_desc.thetext:
If you try to statically instrument a JAR via the ARM Generic Probe and run the JAR in a runtime, this causes problems with vanilla ARM implementation (an implementation other than the TPTP ARM impl). This is caused by the InstrumentationManager which expects the Instrument Agent to be loaded, however, the Instrument Agent is a specific reporting agent for the TPTP ARM implementation. Therefore, if I try to use another vendor's ARM implementation I cannot get the Generic probe to work because the other vendor may not necessary use the RAC as a reporting tool.
We need to make the TPTP ARM impl only depend on the agent being present, the instrumenation should be transparent to these lower level details.
Created an attachment (id=46453) proposed patch
I've tested this using a no-name ARM impl and it works fine. The patch only requires two lines of code changes.
Fix checked in.
Closed.

bug.short_desc: Debugger startup does not handle errors correctly

long_desc.thetext:
I'm starting a debug session on a bproc machine (the machine shouldn't make any difference). After the 'go' command is sent, backend debugger (gdb) is getting an error. I see the following in the console:
*** SEND COMMAND: Go, tasks: 0-9 got debug event: EVENT_DBG_ERROR 03ff 4 Debugger error: Failed to get stack frames from backend ======================= EVENT_DBG_ERROR ====================
This means that the error is being propagated back to the UI. However the debug session remains in the 'starting' state in the UI. Nothing can be done to terminate the job at this point.
The debugger should be more aggressive about dealing with errors, particularly when in the 'starting' state. An error at this point should cause the debugger to terminate (i.e. it should try and terminate or kill the sdm). At the very least, the UI should mark the job as error (or terminated). The debugger should, at all costs, never leave a job in the 'starting' state.

(In reply to comment #0) > I'm starting a debug session on a bproc machine (the machine shouldn't make any > difference). After the 'go' command is sent, backend debugger (gdb) is getting > an error. I see the following in the console: > > *** SEND COMMAND: Go, tasks: 0-9 > got debug event: EVENT_DBG_ERROR 03ff 4 Debugger error: Failed to get stack > frames from backend > ======================= EVENT_DBG_ERROR ==================== > > This means that the error is being propagated back to the UI. However the debug > session remains in the 'starting' state in the UI. Nothing can be done to > terminate the job at this point. > > The debugger should be more aggressive about dealing with errors, particularly > when in the 'starting' state. An error at this point should cause the debugger > to terminate (i.e. it should try and terminate or kill the sdm). At the very > least, the UI should mark the job as error (or terminated). The debugger > should, at all costs, never leave a job in the 'starting' state. >
Did you get this problem again? I set the error type. Different error type will do different action. The types are normal, warning and fatal. If the type is fatal, it will terminate all the processes and then kill the debugger.

Not this exact behavior, but I can reproduce an "Updating annotation..." error (on the Mac at least).
Go into the runtime workspace and remove the executable in the Debug directory. From the Debug directory, recompile the program without specifying -g. i.e. something like 'mpicc -o test test.c'. Then launch the debugger.

(In reply to comment #2) > Not this exact behavior, but I can reproduce an "Updating annotation..." error > (on the Mac at least). > > Go into the runtime workspace and remove the executable in the Debug directory. > From the Debug directory, recompile the program without specifying -g. i.e. > something like 'mpicc -o test test.c'. Then launch the debugger. >

In Linux, it cannot show up the source file and display no source lookup path found, so it should not show "Updating annotation..." error.
